title: Induced current and force - square loop near wire

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows a long, straight conducting wire carrying a current directed toward the top of the page near a conducting square loop. The current in the wire varies with time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> according to the equation <math alttext="I sub W, end sub, of t, equals, beta times t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mi>W</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><mi>t</mi></math> for times <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, where <math alttext="beta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>β</mi></math> is a positive constant. The square loop has side length <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math> and a total resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, and is located with its left edge a distance <math alttext="3 s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>s</mi></math> from the straight wire. The dots to the left, top, and right of Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represent the left, top, and right sides, respectively, of the square loop for times <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>.(a) In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw arrows to indicate the directions and magnitudes of the magnetic forces, if any, exerted on the three sides that are represented. If the magnetic force is zero for any of the sides, write “<math alttext="F sub B, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>B</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” next to the appropriate dot(s). Otherwise, represent each force with an arrow that starts on, and points away from, the appropriate dot.Note: The relative lengths of the arrows should reflect the relative magnitudes of the forces.

(b) The loop is held in place so that it does not move due to the magnetic forces, if any, exerted on the loop. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.

(c) Consider different locations for the loop, and let <math alttext="D sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> be the distance from the straight wire to the left side of the loop, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, draw and label two graphs as follows. Label this curve “<math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.”

In a new scenario, the current in the straight wire is directed downward instead of upward. If it would be the same, say so explicitly. Briefly justify your answer.
